subject: How to decouple classes for unit testing
msgSnippet: ... I m complaining about the ratio of noise to valueable content. The ratio is the same whether it is a 10 message a day or 1000 message a day list. ... The
messageBody:
J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> Pat Farrell wrote:
>> The signal to noise ratio of this mailing list is very low. Some
>> people believe in testing, some don't. There is zero chance that
>> minds will be changed.

> I respect your opinion, but when you complain about the noise on
> such a low-traffic list, I find it difficult to take you seriously.

I'm complaining about the ratio of noise to valueable content. The ratio
is the same whether it is a 10 message a day or 1000 message a day list.


> So many of the questions on this list are from beginners too lazy to
> use Google that, as a balance, I like these discussions (not
> theological rants, by the way--no need to insult--I, for one, am
> pragmatic in my discussion, so would that be applied theology?).

The only sane response to people too lazy to RTFAQ is to give them
a pointer to the faq.

But the "Test Everything no matter" subject itself is an invitation to
flame, not a basis for rational discussion.

Let alone this wonderful exchange:
> > So you're recommending 100% code coverage?
> So you're recommending 0% code coverage?

Sigh.
So, enough naval gazing.

I've written a few over 300 tests, according to JUnit that are executed
by NetBeans for my small project. Most are literally unit tests.
For example, the code that reads configuration files can be tested by
getting the values read.

But other classes are 'controllers' for finite state machines.
The member functions such as process() read input, feed it to the FSA,
and trigger state changes.

What test design approach can decouple the Controller class from the FSA
implementation class?

Similarly, the FSA class calls a 'scribe' class to record significant
events to a database. So the FSA is coupled to the persistance layer,
which is coupled to the JDBC driver.

Clearly one could implement a dummy JDBC driver, but that would most
likely generated more bugs that just using an existing production JDBC
driver.

So how do folks decouple?
